repnme.cdata!:
Lao PDR - Financial management capacity
            building project

abstracts.cdata!:
Financial management capacity building
            (FMCB) initiative supported the government’s efforts to
            enhance its institutional capacity in guiding the
            implementation of its structural reform program in selected
            sectors such as banking and finance, public financial
            management, and state-owned enterprises (SOEs).
            International Development Association (IDA) financing and
            Bank expertise have supported Lao reform efforts to enhance
            fiscal transparency by supporting publishing of audit
            reports and budget reports, eliminate arrears on salaries by
            installing an electronic salary payment system, improve
            management of SOEs by designing restructuring plans and
            conducting financial audits, and improve fiduciary controls
            by supporting establishment of the centralized national
            treasury. In order to continue supporting the Government of
            Lao People's Democratic Republic (PDR) in
            implementation of the public finance management
            strengthening program and supporting institutions for
            external accountability, the Bank is preparing a follow-up
            public finance management project, building on the lessons
            learned from the FMCB project.

docna.cdata!:
Lao PDR - Financial management capacity
            building project

Lao PDR - Financial management
            capacity building project

repnme.cdata!:
Lao - Financial Management Capacity
            Building Project (FMCBP)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Management
            Capacity Building Project (FMCBP) for Lao were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the FMCBP highlights the experience from initially seeking a
            strong project implementation  unit (PIU) organization
            structure to compensate for low national capacity to deliver
            timely outputs to relying on existing capacity for project
            implementation, perhaps at the expense of expediency. While
            a strong PIU could deliver some outputs on time, more often
            than not its staff had to work within the existing low-level
            capacity environment. This critical factor affected the
            project implementation across the board. The FMCBP shows
            that a strong PIU could be effectively used to focus on
            certain critical areas where strong capacity is needed to
            bring about timely results. But for a capacity building
            project in general, it is beneficial to take into account
            and to work with the country's existing capacity and
            given environment to best support the capacity building
            agenda. Due to the need for intensive supervision, a
            technical assistance project would require adequate funding
            and staffing to be able to address and manage challenges at
            the implementation stage, some of which were unexpected and
            unanticipated. The need for intensive supervision will
            clearly benefit from the continuing and close presence of
            the task manager (TM) and the core project team. The TM, in
            close cooperation with other team members in the field and
            at headquarters, maintained the implementation momentum for
            the project through actively coordinating the
            trouble-shooting activities among Bank staff and government
            officials for all the challenges and bottlenecks facing the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Lao PDR - Financial Management Capacity
            Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Financial
            Management Capacity Building Project is to improve the
            Government of Lao PDR (GOL) budget preparation, execution,
            reporting and auditing systems; strengthen monitoring of
            state owned commercial bank operations, and to improve
            financial management of selected state owned enterprises.
            The reallocation is necessary to mainly support the
            increasing requirements for budget training and procurement
            of consultants to carry out fiscal and budget works. The
            reallocations will come from unallocated funds and the civil
            works category. This is a second level restructuring as per
            the new restructuring framework. The requested reallocation
            will not affect the project design, implementation
            arrangements, and scope neither does the reallocation
            require a modification of the project description in the
            financing agreement. The task team was informed that the
            reallocation plan will serve the project until the closing
            date in April 2011.

            Capacity Building Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Lao - Financial Management Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The additional grant for Lao financial
            management capacity building project will finance activities
            for the implementation o f the new organic Budget Law in the
            following areas: developing a new intergovernmental fiscal
            framework; implementation of the revised Chart of Accounts
            and Budget Nomenclature; support to treasury centralization;
            and strengthening external audit capacity. These
            subcomponents will be fully integrated into the restructured
            project framework under the subcomponent supporting the
            Public Expenditure Management Strengthening Program (PEMSP).
